Award.AwardTitle: SCC-Planning: Building Capacity for Smart and Connected Management of Thermal Extremes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the nation's leading cause of weather-related deaths, extreme heat and cold substantially impact human well-being in the United States. The impacts of heat and cold are unevenly distributed in urban areas as a result of variability in infrastructure and social factors that influence risk. Many different agencies, organizations, and individuals are involved in the management of extreme heat and cold events through a wide range of preparedness and response activities. Improved coordination of actions and utilization of data resources would increase the return on public and private investments made to minimize adverse impacts of heat and cold and lead to reduced instances of weather-related mortality, morbidity, discomfort, and lost productivity. This research project will examine existing practices related to the management of heat and cold in the cities of Buffalo, New York, and Tempe, Arizona. The project involves assessment of community partner practices, goals, and needs in these two cities with an emphasis on learning about how partners use and seek data related to weather, health, energy, transit, and other relevant factors. Examination of these two cities will lay the groundwork for a more comprehensive assessment of gaps and opportunities for reducing the impact of thermal extremes in municipalities across the United States, in future research.

The objectives of this planning grant are to work collaboratively with city stakeholders to examine how select cities in the United States are measuring exposure and impacts of thermal extremes on urban residents; document current approaches to and barriers of using existing thermal and related data streams to inform local government strategies and programs; and collaborate with agencies in Tempe and Buffalo, to design a linked research-action approach that integrates social and technological infrastructure to build capacity for communities to manage the impacts of thermal extremes. The scope of the planning grant includes three main outcomes. First, project investigators will work with city stakeholders to pilot an integrated assessment of thermal extremes management in Buffalo and Tempe, which were chosen to represent diverse environmental and social conditions. Second, the investigators and city stakeholders will co-develop a semi-structured interview instrument that can be used for national assessment of thermal extremes management among municipal governments. Finally, the team will co-develop a Smart and Connected Thermal Management integrated conceptual framework. This framework will serve as the basis for future research activities continuing beyond the planning grant period, as well as an organizational tool for municipalities and researchers. The planning grant activity will provide tools for connecting researchers with practice-based approaches for management of thermal extremes. This effort will also provide generalizable approaches and guidance to help city operations become more effective and coordinated overall in managing complex and sometimes competing priorities. The proposed activity will benefit society by advancing our understanding of social-technological approaches to reduce thermal mortality and morbidity while enhancing thermal comfort and well-being.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, Building Capacity for Smart & Connected Management of Thermal Extremes, is a linked research-practice collaboration to address how cities manage extreme cold and heat events. Extreme heat and cold events are collectively responsible for higher death rates than all other weather-related events, and have substantial impacts on people's productivity, urban infrastructure, and urban forests. To various degrees, urban managers make efforts to address these impacts via emergency services, building and energy programs, and landscape ordinances. However, few urban communities have begun to collaboratively address the problem of temperature vulnerability in a systematic and comprehensive way. As climate change and urbanization processes drive urban warming, urban communities - particularly residents who have traditionally been underserved and disenfranchised - will be increasingly vulnerable to temperature-related impacts.

Addressing these temperature vulnerabilities is a complex challenge, as localized microclimates and variation in communities' coping capacities impact the effectiveness of public agencies, organizations, and individuals to respond to extreme cold and heat events. Sectors including energy, buildings, environment, emergency response, social services, and others play a role in managing temperature vulnerability, but those efforts are not always coordinated. This academic-municipal partnership worked from September 2017 through December 2018 to develop a coupled research-planning approach that identifies and addresses the causes of thermal discomfort due to extreme heat and cold. The approach also identifies issues with proactive planning, response, and coordination across professions that manage our urban environments to provide services for people who are vulnerable to those extremes. 

As part of a National Science Foundation-funded Smart & Connected Communities (SCC) planning grant awarded (award # 1737617) in September of 2017, collaborators in Buffalo/Erie County, New York; Tempe/Maricopa County, Arizona; University at Buffalo (UB); UB Regional Institute; Northern Arizona University; the National Weather Service; and Arizona State University (ASU) developed capacity for the emerging field of thermal extremes management. The partnership did this by: 

1) holding two participatory Forums to engage in a deep needs assessment in Buffalo and Tempe; 

2) conducting an integrated assessment of how six (6) United States cities, across varying climate contexts, currently manage heat and cold events.

What has emerged from our capacity-building planning grant activities is a vision for thermally-comfortable communities and a linked research-practice agenda that will inform how these two communities ally with people who are vulnerable to heat and cold-related health impacts for thermal equity and justice. Principles of a thermally-comfortable communities include: 

Thermal Equity- The notion that vulnerable individuals and communities should not be disproportionately burdened with extreme thermal conditions. Residents - particularly low income and traditionally disenfranchised community members - have the capacity to successfully adapt to extreme cold and heat events. 

Minimize Exposure- Residents are proactively protected by urban managers at the necessary place and time to meaningfully reduce exposure to cold and heat hazards.

Accurately Identify Sensitivity- Urban managers require increases in the accuracy of residents' sensitivities to extreme temperatures by using data, community representatives, and connecting people with relevant information to answer the questions of who, when, and where thermal discomfort and illnesses are occurring. Be aware that sensitivity factors may always be incomplete, changing, and/ or emerging sensitivities will likely need to be identified and incorporated.

Enhance Adaptive Capacity- Urban managers shouldtarget interventions that meaningful address thermally vulnerable people and communities? coping deficiencies. Always be alert for and track unintended consequences. 

For agencies to have more effective adaptation/ response to thermal extremes, we suggest that those agencies need better and more current data about neighborhood temperature patterns, coupled with more accurate data on residents' sensitivities and coping capacities to extreme temperatures. Much of this information currently exists in some form, but the data needs to be more focused on the quality, frequency, and scale of data; the way data represents communities' actual sensitivities; and so that it better represents the perspectives of diverse communities in thermal management processes. These are critical steps to create better connections between people with relevant information to answer the questions of who, when, where, and why thermal discomfort and illnesses are occurring. We posit that smart approaches to data infrastructure and better connected and coordinated communication of that data (i.e. collection, analysis, and dissemination of information) between diverse actors within a system of urban managers partnered with researchers will provide more effective structure for oversight, management, and learning to address extreme urban thermal environments.
